titleStmt.title: Letter, James L. Dodds in France to Ellen Smith in Jackson, Tenn., 1919 Apr. 6

publicationStmt.publisher: The University of Tennessee Libraries Digital Initiatives

bibl.title: Letter, James L. Dodds in France to Ellen Smith in Jackson, Tenn., 1919 Apr. 6

projectDesc.p: Machine-readable transcription created for the University of Tennessee Libraries Special Collections.

editorialDecl.p: Errors in transcription of the printed text not controlled.
Editorial tags limited to gap and unclear.
Catchwords and directional notes such as "turn page over" have been omitted.

revisionDesc.change: Approximate date of original transcription and transcriber.
Migrating from P4 to validated TEI P5.

div.p: J. L. Dodds
T Co #8 = 23rd Engir
Miss Ellen Smith
111 Hatton Street
Jackson
Tennessee
U.S.A.
Savilly France
April 6 1919
Dear Ellen
Well at last I resuced a letter from you, and of course you know I was glad to hear from you. I will have to fuss just a little though becasue the letters came so far apart.
I can't understand why you cant hear from me I write you every week I wrote you on my last letter about Tim leaving here.
But for fear you dont get the letter will write it again I sure did hate to see him go for we would visit each other most every week.
and talk of the good times we were going to have when we get back to Jackson and how good 111 Hatton Street would look to us.
Not as much the street as the ones that live there.
I am sure Lin will get there first but my day will come some time or other they wont even tell us when they think we will get home.
Of course they can move us in short maters for we are just a Rgmt. and about 5000 men is alll we have I am sure by the time you get this you will have

Harold back with you if he isnt already, Now let me tell you what I have got to do this week Work in the kitchen and that means peel spuds wash hass and a lots of other things that I dont like a lot, but I cant fuss for is the first time I have been on A. K. P. (kitchen police) since I have been across the pond. I was a cook for about a month when I first came over here. But that is better than this job.
I should worry less I wont do enough to hurt myself at any time.

You were talking about Ernest Warlick he isnt married you are thinking if Ben the one that used to work at the fire dept Ernest was a breakman one the M. S. O. He is on his way back home now. lucky devil and little Caz is going to be a farmer now I know he will be a failure at that

No you didnt step on my toes very much (about gambling.) I never was as bad as some really thought I was. I just have to bet a little on ball games and the races at the fair. Now you wouldnt fuss much about that would you.

I was about to forget to say something about the weather. It is fine here been warm the last week and look as though would stay that way. And I sure hope so. Yes I noticed your letter being longer than usual and hope you will keep up the long ones for I enjoy them so much
Write me real often and the tell me the news A little French
Au revoir Mon Cher
Avec l'amour pour vous
Fayette
